texts.definition: Passageways in games that can only be moved through if certain conditions are met.
markups: <style="Definition">Passageways in games that can only be moved through if certain conditions are met.</style>

Many games have areas that players cannot access before fulfilling certain objectives or goals. <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> are the places in the game worlds that provide the blockage and these may be literal blockages, like a pile of rocks blocking a tunnel, or be more abstract reasons why movement is not possible, e.g. a rocket that will not take off before it is repaired.

Many doors in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Far%20Cry%20series">Far Cry</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style> cannot be opened before players have accessed the proper security cards. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda%20series">The Legend of Zelda series</link></style> requires players to collect keys, defeat boss monsters or manipulate the environment in different ways to open doors. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style> requires players to collect stars to be able to enter levels that are more difficult and thereby guarantee that players have completed easier challenges before ones that are more difficult.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Adventure%20Games">Adventure Games</link></style> like <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Day%20of%20the%20Tentacle">Day of the Tentacle</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leisure%20Suit%20Larry%20series">Leisure Suit Larry series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zork%20series">Zork series</link></style> have meeting the requirements of <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> as major part of their gameplay, although in many cases figuring out what the requirements are is the most difficult part.

Designing <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> consist of first making travel between two points in a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> possible - for example through creating a <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Route</link></style> - and then preventing this <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, and one of the most common reasons for this is to make it possible to open up otherwise <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>. One way of doing this is by inserting <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> - making the removal of the <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> the requirement for opening up the passages. Another is to have <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> that block <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> but having <style="Link"><link="switches">Switches</link></style> (or <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style>) that can remove these. In the case of <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, having <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> that allow players to ignore them is another option. A third is having <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style> that only can be activated under certain circumstances. Places with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/One-Way%20Travel">One-Way Travel</link></style> provide <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> that only depend on from which direction one is approaching them; related to these are <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> that support <style="Link"><link="quick-returns">Quick Returns</link></style> by making returns easy once one as gotten to a specific point. More generally, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> can allow passage through <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style>.

Besides the above options to creating <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style>, these can be modulated by only applying to certain players, require <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style> to use them. They may also require the use of a <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> or not; the latter is often an effect of some <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> being larger than opening or passages. <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> can also be combined or co-located with <style="Link"><link="invisible-walls">Invisible Walls</link></style> to let players see what is one the other side of the passageway, possible to motivate them to try and get passed it.

<style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> may be between parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> that cannot be moved between through continuously <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>. The most usual case of this is <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> between <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> and for games with <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> it is very common - in most cases one has to "complete the level" before being able to go on to the next <style="Link"><link="levels">Level</link></style>.

Not all <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> need to be apparent as potential routes to new areas; the most common reason for this is to create <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style>.

Many games tell stories as a consequence of how players have been able to move to different areas in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. For games designed in this fashion, <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> can be used to ensure that the order in which <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> are unfolded is the one intended.

Meeting the criteria of <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> are <style="Link"><link="access-rewards">Access Rewards</link></style> and <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> are ways of controlling and directing <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> - as a specific example, they can control access between <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, and those that can pass through them have a certain type of <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>. Two effects of using <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> is that they can ensure that <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> are unfolded in a specific order and that players receive both <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> by having to complete easier challenges before trying harder ones. In these ways they can modulate who and when <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals can be completed - if the goal locations are inside (temporarily) <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> these two can create <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals simply because the challenge to get there exists.

<style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> that are unknown to players help define <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style>. Those that are known, and where the requirements to go through them are also known, typically lead to goals of <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> depending on what the specific requirements are.

When <style="CurrentLink">Conditional Passageways</style> limit travel to those that use <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> (as for example the impossibility of tanks to enter most buildings in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%20series">Battlefield series</link></style>), this provides <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> by requiring that all combatants are pedestrians inside buildings. In contrast, when the condition instead is that only specific players or <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> can pass through this can create <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style>.
